analyzeResult.content:
:selected:
Tempe Daily News Tribune December 12, 1995 Page A9
Ever-expanding federal government stealthily constricting individual freedoms
0 ne of the clear messages of the Republican landslide of 1994 was that the public favors the downsizing of government. What is actually occurring is that government is becoming an ever larger part of our lives - like the stealth bomber, we may not see it at first, but it is there.
Some government policy makers and bureaucrats are working ever harder to ehsure their share of the public purse string. A case In point is the Food and Drug Administration. In early 1995, the FDA was pledging to farm out activities thet private agencies could do faster and more effectively and to eliminate regulation that add nothing to public health. Today, however, the FDA is demanding more regulatory powers, requiring a bigger budget and more employees.
David Kessler, the FDA's commissioner, has proven to be an astute pilot of the stealth bomber, steering so that the public does not see where he's going. Kessler, arguing that smoking among the young is a naticeul disaster, exils for increased regulations and draconian penakies for selling and distributing tobacco products to
My turn William J. Boyos
America's young people. The goal is worthwhile but the plan is "stealth"; It isn't there.
The FDA has selected its strategy wisely. The FDA knows that the public is more likely to support increased budgets if the agency claims that it Is supposedly improving health and protecting young people.
The claims of the FDA are smoke and mirrors. The fact is tast FDA regulations wil net reduce smoking among youth. Research shows that the primary cause of smoking by youngsters is peer pressure - the desire to be "cool" and to show independence from parents and
other adults. The more difficult tobacco is percent of Americans say that the federal of rules and regulations created by the to obtain and the more contemptuous adults are of smoking youth, the greater the incentives for the young to smoke. In the Scandinavian natices of Norway. Sweden and Finland, youth smolding had The growth of government has led to an attitude that "someone else is responsible," a decline in personal responsibility; an increasing tendency to place blame for anything on someone else. been dedining until they implemented total bans on tobacco advertising around 1980. Since thon, smoking among the young has risen.
Why then is the FDA so aggressively pushing fee Increased regulations? Possibly because Kessler is aware of public attitudes. The last election notwithstanding, in contrast to just a few decades ago, the public attitude today toward the government's involvement in its lives is much more benign. It is now taken for granted that it is the goverment's responsibility to decide who gets a multitude of goods and Servicos - education, health, safety. jobs and welfare for instance.
In an oneuri survey conducted by the University of Chicago since 1975, the public has been found to Increasingly believe the U.S. government should be Involved in health care and that it is the government's responsibility to help with medical bills. Another poll found that 65
government should bear responsibility for ensuring their company's pension funds; 70 percent say they would not feel safe at their workplace without Washington acting as a watchdog: 73 percent said that they would not feel safe taking a new drug without a clean bill of health from federal regulators; 75 perotat said the same about day-to-day consumer products; 88 percent would not trust the water they drink and the air they breathe if the federal government did not control businesses; 54 percent wanted government to regalate TV programming; 65 percent sald without The federal government, discrimination would be rampant; 75 percent sald endangered species would be in far bigger trouble without government protection. (Arizona Republic, April 21. 1995, page B5).
Goverment In the United States has been a growth industry since 1930. there are now more people employed In government than there are in manufacturing. In 1929, government spending constituted less than 2.5 percent of total spending in the econo-ny: it is now nearly 25 percent. The number
government is so large that it Is mensured by the number of telephone-book-sized pages needed just to list them.
We sue our employers because we are depressed; we sue a firm because we spilled coffee on ourselves; we sue our neighbor because we were not watching where we were going and we tripped; we sus our teachers because we were umwilling to work in school and thus did not learn; we que the tobacco companies because we decided to smoke; and on and on.
The FDA is well aware of the public'si . attitude and has developed a strategy that Is likely to lead to continued growth and power. The FDA's proposals won't reduce yourh smoking, but they will farther restrict individual freedoms. Beware of wise men offering fool's gold.
William J. Bayes is a professor in the Department of Economics at Arizona State University
